At 01:59 29/10/2004 +0100, you wrote:

>Ian Badcoe wrote:
>
> >Hi,
> >         I've never heard of it, but an obvious interpretation springs from
> >the name...
> >
> >         What it sounds like, is a neurone with some "memory" in that it
> >keeps a variable from update to update, and its update function would look
> >something like:
> >
> >         var' = var * f + weighted_sum(input);           f < 1.0
> >
> >         So var integrates input across updates, and f acts to slowly leak
> >away the old contents...
> >
> >         whether the output is var itself or f(var) is, I guess, your 
> choice...
> >
> >         Ian
> >
> >p.s. presumably you can built one of these from a few standard neurones?
> >
> >
>Absolutely. From your explanation I would say that this same effect
>could be achieved with a recursive connection from a neuron's output
>back into its input. So from that perspective you could say that NEAT as
>it stands can represent this type of functionality through its topology
>searching propoperties. However, relying on topology searching to find
>solutions might not be as effective as actually defining a leaky
>integrater neuron directly. This comes back to our previous [brief]
>discussion regarding implementing different types of neuron and
>activation function - which I hope to look into soon.

Except after I suggest this, it occurred to me that completely standard 
neurones would put unwanted sigmoids onto the definition.  e.g. taking your 
idea of a single feedback connection within a single node we would have:


          var' = sigmoid(var * f + weighted_sum(input));

Rather than:

          var' = var * f + weighted_sum(input);

[[var * f is the effect of the feedback connection, obviously one would 
normally just regard this as part of the weighted sum over inputs but I'm 
writting it separately so we can see it :) ]]

Which brings us back to the point we had briefly some months ago, where 
some equations fit reasonably nicely into an ANN framework, but because 
they depend so heavily on the linear portion of of the sigmoids, their 
weights are constrained so much that it is almost impossible to evolve 
them.  Remember when we discusses whether one could evolve networks for A + 
B or A * B using sigmoidal neurones?

         Ian
